body_text.text: Observation of B 0 s → J/ψ K * (892) 0 and B 0 s → J/ψ K 0 S decays A. Ruiz, 9 J. Russ, 10 V. Rusu, 15 A. Safonov, 51 W.K. Sakumoto, 47 Y. Sakurai, 56 L. Santi f f , 52 L. Sartori, 44 K. Sato, 53 V. Saveliev t , 42 A. Savoy-Navarro, 42 P. Schlabach, 15 A. Schmidt, 24 E.E. Schmidt, 15 M.P. Schmidt * , 59 M. Schmitt, 36 T. Schwarz, 7 L. Scodellaro, 9 A. Scribano cc , 44 F. Scuri, 44 A. Sedov, 46 S. Seidel, 35 Y. Seiya, 39 A. Semenov, 13 F. Sforza bb , 44 A. Sfyrla, 22 S.Z. Shalhout, 7 T. Shears, 27 P.F. Shepard, 45 M. Shimojima s , 53 S. Shiraishi, 11 M. Shochet, 11 I. Shreyber, 34 A. Simonenko, 13 P. Sinervo, 31 A. Sissakian * , 13 K. Sliwa, 54 J.R. Smith, 7 F.D. Snider, 15 A. Soha, 15   15 A. Zanetti, 52 Y. Zeng, 14 and S. Zucchelli z 6 (CDF Collaboration † )
We report the first observation of two Cabibbo-suppressed decay modes of the B 0 s meson.

Using a sample of pp collisions at √ s = 1.96 TeV corresponding to 5.9 fb −1 of integrated luminosity collected with the CDF II detector at the Fermilab Tevatron, we search for new B 0 s decay modes in a sample of events containing J/ψ → µ + µ − decays.
We reconstruct a B 0 s → J/ψ K * (892) 0 signal with K * (892) 0 → K + π − , observing a yield of 151 ± 25 events with a statistical significance of 8.0σ.
We also reconstruct a B 0 s → J/ψ K 0 S signal with K 0 S → π + π − , observing a yield of 64 ± 14 events with a statistical significance of 7.2σ.

From these yields, we extract the branching ratios B(B 0 s → J/ψ K * (892) 0 ) = (8.3 ± 3.8) × 10 −5 and B(B 0 s → J/ψ K 0 ) = (3.5 ± 0.8) × 10 −5 , where statistical, systematic, and fragmentation-fraction uncertainties are included in the combined uncertainty.
I. INTRODUCTION

This paper presents the first observation of the Cabibbo-suppressed decays B 0 s → J/ψK * 0 (892) and B 0 s → J/ψ K 0 S (and the corresponding charge conjugate decays) using a sample derived from an integrated luminosity of 5.9 fb −1 of proton-antiproton collisions at √ s = 1.96 TeV produced at the Fermilab Tevatron.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

Stefan Institute, Ljubljana, Slovenia, K * 0 (892), and B 0 → J/ψ K 0 S ) to extract the branching ratios for these newly observed B 0 s decay modes.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: With the establishment of the decay modes presented here, future measurements can be considered that will further aid our experimental investigation into the physics of the B 0 s system.

body_text.text: The success of the CKM threegeneration description of charge conjugation-parity inversion (CP ) violation [1] in the bottom and kaon sectors has continued to motivate additional, more precise tests of CP violation in the flavor sector.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: In recent years, attention has turned to the B 0 s meson as new territory to explore the possibility of non-standard-model contributions, specifically in the CKM matrix element V ts .
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Precise measurement of the frequency of B 0 s flavor oscillations [2] has significantly limited the magnitude of new physics amplitudes.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: However, possible large new physics phases remain poorly constrained.

body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The decay B 0 s → J/ψ K * (892) 0 is a pseudoscalar to vector-vector transition and can be used to help disentangle penguin contributions in B 0 s → J/ψ φ [4].
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: With a sufficiently large data sample, it would be possible to measure ∆Γ B 0 s and the polarization amplitudes.
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Furthermore, the Cabibbo-suppressed decay B 0 s → J/ψ K 0 S is a CP -odd final state (ignoring CP violation in the kaon system) and therefore a measurement of the lifetime in this decay mode is a direct measure of Γ B 0 sH = 1/τ B 0 sH .
body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: With a larger data sample, a tagged CP asymmetry analysis of the B 0 s → J/ψ K 0 S mode, in conjunction with our precise knowledge of CP violation in B 0 → J/ψ K 0 S , can yield information on the angle γ of the unitarity triangle [5].

body_text.section: I. INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: II.
CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES
The data used in these analyses correspond to an integrated luminosity of 5.9 fb −1 and were collected by the CDF II detector from March 2002 to February 2010 using di-muon triggers.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The CDF II detector is a general purpose, cylindrically symmetric detector.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: A more detailed description can be found elsewhere [7].
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The sub-detectors relevant for these analyses are briefly discussed here.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Charged particle trajectories (tracks) are measured by a system comprised of eight layers of silicon microstrip detector (SVX) and an open-cell wire drift chamber (COT), both immersed in a 1.4 T axial magnetic field.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The silicon detector [8] extends from a radius of 1.5 cm to 22 cm and has a single-hit resolution of approximately 15 µm.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The COT drift chamber [9] provides up to 96 measurements from radii of 40 cm to 137 cm and covers the range |η| ≤1 [10].
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The combined COT+SVX charged particle momentum resolution is σ pT /p T 2 = 0.07% [GeV/c ] −1 , which leads to a mass resolution on the K 0 S → π + π − signal of 0.006 GeV/c 2 .
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Outside the calorimeters reside four layers of planar drift chambers [11] (CMU) that detect muons with transverse momentum p T >1.4 GeV/c within |η| < 0.6.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Additional chambers and scintillators [12] (CMX) cover 0.6< |η| <1.0 for muons with p T >2 GeV/c.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The di-muon triggers collect a sample of J/ψ → µ + µ − candidates.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: At the first level of a three-level trigger system, an electronic track processor (XFT) [13] uses COT information to find tracks and extrapolate [14] those with p T >1.5(2.0) GeV/c to track segments in the CMU (CMX) muon-chambers.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Events pass this first trigger level if two or more XFT tracks are matched to muonchamber track segments.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The second trigger level requires those tracks to have opposite charge and an appropriate opening angle in the plane transverse to the beamline.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Finally, at level 3, full tracking information is used to reconstruct J/ψ → µ + µ − candidates.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Events with a candidate in the mass range 2.7 to 4.0 GeV/c 2 are accepted.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: To identify B 0 and B 0 s decay candidates, we pair J/ψ candidates with K 0 S → π + π − and K * 0 → K + π − candidates.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The reconstruction of K 0 S → π + π − and K * 0 → K + π − candidates starts from pairs of oppositely-charged tracks fit to a common interaction point (vertex).
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: In the B 0 s → J/ψ K 0 S analysis, we reconstruct two tracks as pions and combine them to define a K 0 S candidate, where the invariant mass of the two pions is constrained to the known K 0 S mass [3].
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: In the B 0 s → J/ψ K * 0 analysis, we reconstruct the K * 0 candidate from the combination of a π and a K. If two K * 0 candidates are reconstructed with the same tracks, with the only difference that the kaon and pion hypotheses are interchanged, we select the K * 0 candidate whose mass is closer to the pole value of 896 MeV/c 2 .
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We perform a kinematic fit of each B candidate where the final-state tracks are constrained to come from a common decay point and the invariant mass of the muon pair is constrained to the known J/ψ mass [3].
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: These preliminary selection criteria for B 0 and B 0 s candidates are listed in Table I. Additional selection criteria optimized for the individual channels are described in Secs.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: III and IV.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Simulated samples of B 0 and B 0 s decays are used to optimize event selection, model signal distributions, and assess systematic uncertainties.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: For our default Monte Carlo simulation (MC) samples, we generate single b hadrons according to the predicted next-to-leading order QCD calculation [15].
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: For systematic studies, we also generate single b hadrons according to momentum and rapidity spectra measured by CDF [7].
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: These hadrons are then decayed using the evtgen package [16] and fed into a geant simulation of the CDF detector [17].
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The simulated data are then processed and reconstructed in the same manner as the detector data.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: In the case of J/ψK * 0 mode, it is necessary to specify the polarization parameters in the simulation.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: For both B 0 and B 0 s , we use transversity basis [18] polarization amplitudes |A 0 | 2 = 0.6 and |A ⊥ | 2 = 0.22, which are similar to the PDG values of |A 0 | 2 = 0.571 ± 0.008 and |A ⊥ | 2 = 0.22±0.013 [3].
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: For systematic acceptance studies, MC samples with other polarization values were generated.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: In all of the MC samples generated, and throughout the analyses presented below, we assume that there is no CP violation in B 0 s mixing or decay.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We also assume that equal numbers of B 0 andB 0 mesons, as well as equal numbers of B 0 s andB 0 s mesons, are produced in the pp collisions.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: In this untagged analysis that does not distinguish B → J/ψK 0 S fromB → J/ψK 0 S , the observed yield is unaffected by CP violation provided that equal numbers of B andB mesons are produced at t = 0.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We optimize the selection criteria to provide the highest likelihood for evidence of this mode.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: This is done by maximizing S/(1.5 + √ B), where S refers to the number of signal events and B is the number of background events in the signal region.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Reference [19] demonstrates that this quantity is well suited for discovery.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: For the signal sample, a B 0 s → J/ψ K * 0 MC sample is used.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: For the background sample, we use J/ψ K * 0 candidate events from data with the requirement that the reconstructed candidate mass M B falls in the range 5.6 GeV/c 2 < M B < 5.8 GeV/c 2 .
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: This "upper sideband" region contains events kinematically similar to the combinatorial background in the signal region and is not contaminated by residual signal events.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We avoid using the sideband below the B 0 peak because it is contaminated with partially reconstructed B decays such as B 0 → J/ψK * 0 π 0 .
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We optimize simultaneously over the transverse momenta p T (π − ) and p T (K + ), the B 0 s transverse decay length L xy (B 0 s ), and the B 0 s decay kinematicfit probability.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The final cuts we use are
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: s ) > 300 µm and fit probability greater than 10 −5 .
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Particle identification using specific ionization (dE/dx) in the COT was evaluated to further separate K * 0 → K + π − from π + π − and K + K − backgrounds.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Although further background reduction could be achieved, the corresponding reduction in signal efficiency rendered particle identification unprofitable, and we choose not to use it.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We determine the B 0 s and B 0 yields using a binned likelihood fit in the candidate masses.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We model the signal contributions with templates composed of three Gaussians obtained from fits to B 0 MC.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The two dominant, narrow Gaussians model detector resolution effects and also account for cases where the identities of the π and K from the K * 0 decay are interchanged.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: As mentioned above, some events are identified where a single pair of tracks pass the selection requirements under both the π-K and K-π hypotheses.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: In those cases, we reconstruct the event using both sets of π/K assignments and then choose candidate whose particle assignment yields a reconstructed mass that is closer to the nominal K * (892) mass.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: This technique ensures that candidates are not used twice.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Approximately 10% of B → J/ψK * 0 events are reconstructed with the incorrect π-K assignment.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: These events peak at the B masses, but have a significantly broader width.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: A wide Gaussian models misreconstructed signal events and other non-Gaussian resolution effects.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The relative contributions, means, and widths of each Gaussian are fixed in the fit.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The B 0 s templates used in the fit are identical to B 0 templates, except for a shift of 86.8 MeV/c 2 in the mean value of the three Gaussians.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: This value corresponds to the known [3,20] mass difference between B 0 s and B 0 .
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The MC slightly underestimates the mass resolution, so the widths of the two narrow Gaussians are multiplied by a scale factor common to the B 0 and B 0 s templates, which is allowed to float in the fit.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The scale factor is not applied to the third Gaussian since the resolution effects are negligible compared to the other effects.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Moreover, a common mass shift is added to the means of all Gaussian templates to account for a possible mass mismodeling in the MC.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: This mass shift is floating in the fit.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The B 0 s → J/ψ K * 0 analysis has three primary background contributions: events with random track combinations (combinatorics), partially reconstructed b hadrons, and B 0 s → J/ψ φ decays.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Combinatorial background arises from sources such as a real J/ψ plus two other tracks, where the J/ψ could be either prompt or coming from a B decay.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Another source arises from false J/ψ candidates reconstructed from misidentified hadrons.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The combinatorial background is non-peaking and accurately modeled in the fit with an exponential function.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Backgrounds from partially reconstructed b hadrons come from multibody decays where a π, K, or γ is not reconstructed, for example, the decay mode B 0 → J/ψK * 0 π 0 .
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We fit this background with two ARGUS functions [21], one for partially reconstructed B 0 and another for partially reconstructed B 0 s .
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The ARGUS function parameterization for m < m 0 is
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: where m 0 is the mass cutoff, C the decay constant, and N 1 is the normalization.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The function is set to zero for m > m 0 .
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The ARGUS function for partially reconstructed B 0 has a fixed mass cutoff of m(B 0 ) − m(π 0 ) = 5.140 GeV/c 2 and the function for partially reconstructed B 0 s has a fixed mass cutoff of m(B 0 s ) − m(π 0 ) = 5.220 GeV/c 2 .
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The decay constants of the two functions are constrained to be the same, and the normalizations are independent.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Each ARGUS function is convoluted with a Gaussian having a width of 12 MeV/c 2 to account for detector resolution effects.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Since it is possible for B 0 s → J/ψ φ candidates to pass the J/ψ K * 0 reconstruction criteria, B 0 s → J/ψ φ must be considered as a background.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We use a template consisting of two Gaussians, extracted from simulation, to model this background in the J/ψ K * 0 fit, where both Gaussians are primarily modeling detector resolution effects.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We fix to the template values the widths, means, and relative contributions from each Gaussian in the final fit.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We multiply the constant width of the narrower Gaussian by the same scale factor used in the signal templates.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We constrain the B 0 s → J/ψ φ contribution in the J/ψ K * 0 fit by measuring the yield of B 0 s → J/ψ φ in the data using selection criteria efficient for reconstructing B 0 s → J/ψ φ.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We then use simulation to calculate the fraction of those J/ψ φ events that would satisfy the J/ψ K * 0 selection.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We perform a binned log likelihood fit to the J/ψ Kπ invariant mass distribution using the templates for signals and the background functions described above.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The mass distributions in data for J/ψ K * 0 candidates and the final fit appear in Fig. 1.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The yields for B 0 → J/ψ K * 0 and B 0 s → J/ψ K * 0 signal are 9530 ± 110 and 151 ± 25 respectively.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The ratio N (B 0 s → J/ψ K * 0 )/N (B 0 → J/ψ K * 0 ) is 0.0159 ± 0.0022 (stat).
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We determine the statistical significance of the B 0 s → J/ψ K * 0 signal by fitting the mass distribution without the B 0 s contribution (background-only hypothesis).
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: For likelihood L, we interpret −2 log L as a χ 2 distribution.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We use ∆χ 2 with one degree of freedom to determine that the probability of background fluctuations producing a comparable or greater signal is 8.9×10 −16 or 8.0σ.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: This is the first observation of the B 0 s → J/ψ K * 0 decay.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We consider several sources of systematic uncertainty in the measured ratio of N (B 0 s → J/ψ K * 0 )/N (B 0 → J/ψ K * 0 ).
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The modeling of the B 0 and B 0 s signal peaks can influence the ratio.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: To quantify the effect of the mismodeling we repeat the fit using two Gaussian templates instead of three for the signal.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The fit value of N (B 0 s )/N (B 0 ) is shifted by 7×10 −4 .
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We vary the input mass difference between B 0 and B 0 s in the templates within its uncertainty of 0.7 MeV/c 2 .
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The difference in N (B 0 s → J/ψ K * 0 )/N (B 0 → J/ψ K * 0 ) with the alternate templates is 2×10 −5 .
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: This is sufficiently small that we ascribe no systematic uncertainty due to the mass difference uncertainty.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The modeling of the combinatorial background is another source of systematic uncertainty.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: To explore the sensitivity to the choice parameterization, we use a power function (f(m)=km α , with k and α free parameters) instead of an exponential.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The overall fit quality with the power function is similar to that obtained using an exponential model.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We assign the difference in relative yield as a background modeling systematic uncertainty of 2×10 −4 on the relative branching ratio.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: In the likelihood fit, we allow the combinatorial background contribution to float.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We performed a study to evaluate how the ratio of yields depends upon the specific, arbitrary choice of the fit range.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We compare the main fit, which allows the combinatorial background to float over the entire fit range, to a control case where the combinatorial contribution is fitted in the upper sideband and extrapolated to the full mass range prior to the final fit.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Due to the difference in the result from these two methods, we include a systematic uncertainty of 0.0050 on the N (B 0 s → J/ψ K * 0 )/N (B 0 → J/ψ K * 0 ) ratio.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Several sources contribute to an uncertainty in the B 0 s → J/ψ φ contribution.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: While there is 30% uncertainty in the branching ratio, the dominant uncertainty arises from the uncertainty in the B 0 s → J/ψ φ template, given that we rely on MC to derive this.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: To perform a conservative assessment of this uncertainty, we repeated the fit while doubling the fraction of B 0 s → J/ψ φ candidates.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The resulting shift of 2×10 −4 is assigned as the uncertainty in the B 0 s → J/ψ φ contribution.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We add the different systematic uncertainty contributions, summarized in Table II, in quadrature resulting in  a final value
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

ref_spans.text: Table II, in quadrature resulting in  a final value

body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The B 0 s → J/ψ K 0 S decay has several differences compared to the B 0 s → J/ψ K * 0 decay.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: It contains a K 0 S , which has a relatively long lifetime of cτ =2.68 cm.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We use the displacement between the reconstructed K 0 S decay point and the reconstructed B decay point in the event selection to reduce backgrounds such as B 0 s → J/ψ φ.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Finally, as in the B 0 system, we expect the B 0 s → J/ψ K 0 S signal to be smaller than that of the B 0 s → J/ψ K * 0 mode.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Therefore, we use a Neural Network (NN) technique to take full advantage of all the kinematic variables and their correlations.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We use the NeuroBayes [22] NN package.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The NN provides an output value close to +1 for signal-like events and near −1 for background-like events.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We train the NN using simulated B 0 s MC events as a signal sample.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We use data from the upper sideband in the J/ψ K 0 S candidate mass distribution, well separated from the signal region, as a background training sample.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We use as inputs for the NN the quantities listed in Table III.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: These input quantities are chosen as variables with good discriminating power which, alone or in combination, do not bias the mass spectrum.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: After the training, the NN achieves strong discrimination between signal and background as shown in Fig. 2a.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: As in the B 0 s → J/ψ K * 0 analysis, we optimize the selection by maximizing S/(1.5 + √ B).
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The signal S is modeled using B 0 s MC events in the reconstructed mass range 5.350 GeV/c 2 < M B < 5.400 GeV/c 2 .
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The background B is modeled using J/ψ K 0 S candidates in data populating the mass range 5.430 GeV/c 2 < M B < 5.480 GeV/c 2 .
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The figure of merit suggests a cut value in the NN response of 0.88 as shown in Fig. 2b.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The fitting technique is similar to the B 0 s → J/ψ K * 0 analysis.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We obtain the yields of B 0 → J/ψ K 0 S and B 0 s → J/ψ K 0 S signals in a binned likelihood fit to the invariant mass distribution.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We again model the B 0 and B 0 s signal contributions with three Gaussian templates obtained from fitting B 0 → J/ψ K 0 S MC and use the mass difference between B 0 s and B 0 for the formation of the B 0 s → J/ψ K 0 S template.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The two major sources of background in this analysis are combinatorial background and partially reconstructed b-hadron decays.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We model these with the same functional forms used in the B 0 → J/ψ K * 0 analysis.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: However, we include only one ARGUS function because the contribution of partially reconstructed B 0 s is negligible.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: An additional background in this analysis is Λ b 0 → J/ψ Λ decays where the p from the Λ decay is assumed to be a π.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: In order to suppress the Λ b 0 contribution, we apply a cut to the angular variable cos(θ K 0 S ,π2 ), where θ K 0 S ,π2 is the angle between the K 0 S candidate p T in the lab frame and the lower p T pion (π 2 ) in the K 0 S center-of-mass frame.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Cutting out events with cos(θ K 0 S ,π2 )< -0.75 removes 99.8% of the Λ b 0 while retaining 86% of the B 0 s .
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The residual Λ b 0 contamination is less than one event and is neglected.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The invariant mass distribution for J/ψ K 0 S and the fit result including the different contributions are shown in Fig. 3.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We determine the yields of the B 0 → J/ψ K 0 S and B 0 s → J/ψ K 0 S signal to be 5954 ± 79 and 64 ± 14 respectively.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: As with the B 0 s → J/ψ K * 0 case, we determine the statistical significance of the B 0 s → J/ψ K 0 S signal by fitting the mass distribution without the B 0 s contribution (background-only hypothesis), a difference of one degree of freedom between the two hypotheses.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: For likelihood L we interpret −2 log L as a χ 2 and use the difference in that quantity to determine that the probability of background fluctuations producing a comparable or greater signal is 3.9×10 −13 or 7.2σ.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The value of
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The sources of systematic uncertainty are similar to the other analysis.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: In this case the absolute uncertainties for the ratio are 6×10 −4 from the combinatorial background contribution, 6×10 −4 from the combinatorial background modeling, 5×10 −4 from the signal modeling and 1.3×10 −5 from the mass difference between B 0 and B 0 s .
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The systematic uncertainties are summarized in Table II.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We sum the contributions in quadrature resulting in a total systematic uncertainty of ±0.0010.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The final
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: To determine the ratio of branching ratios B(B 0 s → J/ψ K)/B(B 0 → J/ψ K), where K represents K 0 S or K * 0 , the relative acceptances of B 0 → J/ψ K 0 S to B 0 s → J/ψ K 0 S and B 0 → J/ψ K * 0 to B 0 s → J/ψ K * 0 need to be determined.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We use MC samples to extract A rel as follows:
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: where N (gen) is the number of MC generated signal events, N (pass) is the number of events passing all selection requirements, and K represents K 0 S or K * 0 .
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We determine the value for A rel to be 1.057 ± 0.010 for the K * 0 channel and 1.012 ± 0.010 for the K 0 S channel.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: In both channels, the kinematics of the B 0 and B 0 s final states are very similar to one another.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The value for A rel in the K * 0 channel is larger than unity because the transverse decay length selection criteria removes more B 0 s than B 0 due to the fact the B 0 lifetime is longer than the average B 0 s lifetime.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: In the K 0 S channel, A rel is close to unity because the B 0 s lifetime is the long-lived CP component and therefore close to the B 0 lifetime.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We determine the statistical uncertainty on the acceptances for B 0 and B 0 s , assuming binomial statistics.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: This MC statistical uncertainty is reported as a systematic uncertainty on A rel .
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The data sample utilized in this analysis was acquired using a number of variations on the J/ψ → µ + µ − trigger.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We have verified that the acceptance calculation is robust and consistent across all kinematic variations of these triggers.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Several other effects contribute to the systematic uncertainty on A rel .
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Uncertainty in B 0 s and B 0 lifetimes introduces an uncertainty on the acceptance through the transverse decay length requirement.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: For B 0 s → J/ψ K 0 S analysis, we generate different MC samples, varying the lifetimes by one standard deviation with respect to their measured values.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We use the average measured value for B 0 and the evaluated τ B 0 sH value for B 0 s [3].
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The maximum deviation of A rel is 0.028, and we take this value as a systematic uncertainty.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: For the B 0 s → J/ψ K * 0 analysis, the procedure to evaluate the systematic uncertainty is slightly different.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The B 0 s → J/ψ K * 0 decay is an unknown admixture of CP -even and CP -odd states which have different lifetimes.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The world-average currently gives ∆Γ B 0 s /Γ B 0 s = 0.092 +0.051 −0.054 for Γ B 0 s = 1 2 (Γ B 0 sH + Γ B 0 sL ) [3], where Γ B 0 sH and Γ B 0 sL are the widths of the heavy and light mass eigenstates respectively.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: If the B 0 s were either all B 0 sH or B 0 sL , the maximum lifetime change would be 5%.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: To evaluate the effect on A rel , we reweight the default B 0 s → J/ψ K * 0 lifetime distribution.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The reweighting is performed by normalizing the default lifetime distribution and comparing it to distributions with the lifetime increased or decreased by 5%.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: This leads to a maximum deviation on A rel of 0.046.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Another source of systematic uncertainty arises from the momentum spectra of the B 0 and B 0 s .
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Since we normalize our B 0 s signal to the B 0 mode, we are sensitive only to mismodeling in the ratio of p T (B 0 ) versus p T (B 0 s ), which should be quite small.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We compare the default B 0 s and B 0 samples which use a next-to-leading order QCD calculation [15] to the p T spectrum measured by CDF [7].
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: In the B 0 s → J/ψ K * 0 analysis, the value of A rel varies by 0.029 when using these alternative production spectra and we take this value as a systematic uncertainty.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Likewise, for the B 0 s → J/ψ K 0 S analysis, the change in A rel is 0.032.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Our relative acceptance is calculated assuming that the polarization in B 0 s → J/ψK * is identical to the polarization in B 0 → J/ψK * .
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Since we have no a priori knowledge of the actual polarization in the B 0 s mode, we compute the systematic uncertainty by allowing all possible values for the polarization.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: We generated MC samples for A 0 = 1, A = 1, and A ⊥ = 1.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: The maximum variation from any of these polarizations leads to a systematic uncertainty on A rel of 0.261.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Since the angular distributions arising from polarization are clearly the dominant systematic uncertainty, we have neglected the correlation between polarization and lifetime in assessing the uncertainties.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Table IV shows a summary of the systematic uncertainties on A rel for both measurements.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: Summing these contributions in quadrature, we find A rel = 1.057 ± 0.010 (stat) ± 0.267 (syst) for the K * 0 analysis and A rel = 1.012 ± 0.010 (stat) ± 0.042 (syst) for the K 0 S analysis.
body_text.section: II. CDF DETECTOR, DATA, AND MONTE CARLO SAMPLES

body_text.text: VI.
RESULTS
Using the values of A rel described above, we find
body_text.section: VI. RESULTS

body_text.text: and
body_text.section: VI. RESULTS

body_text.text: To determine the ratio of branching ratios, we combine these results with the most recent CDF measurement [6] of f s /(f u + f d )× B(D s → φπ) and f u /f d with the current world-average value [3] for B(D s → φπ) to yield f s /f d = 0.269 ± 0.033.
body_text.section: VI. RESULTS

body_text.text: We quote the systematic uncertainty coming from the f s /f d uncertainty as "frag".
body_text.section: VI. RESULTS

body_text.text: The ratio of branching fractions to the reference B 0 decays are:
body_text.section: VI. RESULTS

body_text.text: and
body_text.section: VI. RESULTS

body_text.text: The relative branching ratios observed for both modes are in good agreement with the expectation based upon the pure spectator model.
body_text.section: VI. RESULTS

body_text.text: We use the world-average values for B(B 0 → J/ψ K * 0 ) and B(B 0 → J/ψ K 0 ) [3] for normalization to calculate the absolute branching fractions:
body_text.section: VI. RESULTS
VI. RESULTS

body_text.text: In conclusion, we present the first observation and branching ratio measurement of the Cabibbo suppressed decays B 0 s → J/ψ K * 0 and B 0 s → J/ψ K 0 S .
body_text.section: VI. RESULTS

body_text.text: With larger data samples and additional analysis, these modes can be used to further explore the properties of the B 0 s system.
body_text.section: VI. RESULTS
